job_title: Physical Therapist in Cedar Park, TX
pros: I've worked for this hospital for a long time and they've consistently given merit increases every year based on performance. When we couldn't work during the freeze in February 2021 and had to use PTO, they gave it back to us in our PTO bank. They show appreciation for their employees on a regular basis with different events providing free lunch/dinner/coffee and other gifts. To stay competitive with pay rates and help retention, they've been proactive with market analysis of each job title which has resulted in increases to our hourly rate in addition to the annual merit increase.
cons: No cons. This is a great place to work!

review_title: Terrible Management and Leadership from the top down
job_title: Registered Nurse in Austin, TX
pros: The only two reasons I’ve stayed at this job is because of my awesome co-workers and doctors. The second reason is I’m comfortable and not looking to change jobs in the middle of a pandemic.
cons: Leadership from the corporate level down to the unit managers is awful. These positions are revolving door and it’s rare to have a manager in their spot longer than a year. Either they get a good manager and they try to advocate for their staff and make positive change or they are a yes man and only do what upper management wants them to do. The good ones either leave or get pushed out because they try to make positive changes regarding staffing and patient care and that’s just simply not allowed here. They have terrible staff retention rates and often spend tens of thousands for sign on bonuses for new staff(that end up leaving shortly after orientation) instead of taking care of the staff that’s currently there and getting a 5 CENT raise annually. All they care about is the bottom line...MONEY. Patient care continues to decline and so do employee satisfaction rates.

review_title: A lot of paperwork, not much infrastructure

pros: Place is willing to let you cross into other departments
cons: Not willing to increase pay, no training or infrastructure for how departments are ran.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Lago Vista, TX

job_title: Registered Nurse in Cedar Park, TX
pros: Growing hospital and located in good area
cons: Lack of staff appreciation and communication

job_title: Registered Nurse in Cedar Park, TX
pros: I enjoyed the other nurses that I worked with. We worked hard as a team and helped each other out.
cons: The nursing management had no problem working the nurses short staffed, and expected us to care for patients we had no previous experience caring for.  This was not fair to the patients or the nursing staff that cared for them. The nursing staff did everything. There were no patient techs, help answering the phones or doors, lab technicians for lab draws leaving the care provided short changed. There was little to no effective communication between the units in the women's center resulting in care not being as high quality as it could have been. Last, but not least, as a RN, I felt like I had no support from management. They were not effective at handling any concerns or issues.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cedar Park, TX
pros:
I have had nothing but a positive experience during my time so far with CPRMC, starting with the first initial phone call from the Recruiting/HR department and throughout the entire onboarding process, I have been surrounded by a great team and supportive managers. During my peer interview, the managers were very approachable and took time to discuss their goals and growth plans and I felt confident they would be a great team to work with. 

I've never worked for a company that truly makes you feel like you are valued and appreciated the way CPRMC has done and it shows me I made the right decision coming here. The hospital is still young and may have had its challenges and growing pains in previous years, but it seems they are on the right track and I look forward to being a part of the growth.
cons: I haven't noticed anything out of the ordinary and my manager has been great at soliciting my feedback and suggestions.

job_title: in Cedar Park, TX
pros: Close to home, great location. It's new and clean.
cons:
Workflow is unstable and there are frequent gaps in shift coverage hospital wide.
The layout of the hospital and parking is very disorganized and a maze to navigate through for such a small hospital.
Management turnover is too frequent and ineffective.
Overall the hospital is wasteful and badly managed.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Cedar Park, TX
pros: Great location, easy access and good management for the most part.  I didn't ever see the people from the administrative offices.  The management on my unit did listen to their employees.
cons: I didn't like not knowing the doctors here.  They have way too many on staff and so there was no consistency.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cedar Park, TX
pros: This organization has made significant improvements over prior years, in terms of recruiting the highest caliber of clinical and non clinical staff. The organization is very much focused on employee retention and offering competitive salaries.  This is the type of organization that you feel valued and have a voice. In fact, i look forward to coming to work. It doesn't matter what our role, upper management engages all and truly cares about staff. I can not say that about previous employers!   I have been here over 5 years and to see the transformation in all areas is a joy to watch and an honor to be a part of. I have no plans of leaving any time soon.
cons: Some bad reputation issues from YEARS past that are completely irrelevant now, so many years later.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Austin, TX
pros:
-Pay is very competitive with Austin area
-Employees can use ER for just $100 copay

-Dr's are easy to work with

review_title: Pleasant on average, but treated like a employee number rather than a human being.
job_title: Surgical Technologist in Cedar Park, TX
pros: Nice benefits package, nice work space, nice cafe with good food, plenty of parking, easily accessible, continuing education units are easy to sign up for, BLS/ACLS training
cons:
Expected to work a full day of scheduled patients, after having been called in while on-call, working several hours into the wee morning hours, cleaning all instrumentation, possibly sterilizing instruments/equipment for the first cases scheduled,  and getting perhaps 2 hours of rest. Plain and simple it is not safe for the patient, the employee, nor their team members relying on them to do their job with a clear sharp professional mind. 

I realize it is a sad but true industry standard to work medical staff to their bones, but isn't it time that techs and nurses get treated with respect and dignity as well as the physicians & patients? I heard a lot from other employees about working so hard to start this hospital up and get it going with patients and doctors, going through nurse manager after department manager, and still they work extremely long hours and back up in the hospital at 6 or 7 am. 

No one should get written up for trying to work safely with patients lives in our hands.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cedar Park, TX
